questions.text: Wolfram’s syndrome includes all except:
questions.solution:
• Pituitary adenoma is not a part of wolfram syndrome.
  • Wolfram syndrome (rare autosomal recessive disease ;chromosome 4;mitochondrial)
    • Diabetes insipidus
    • Diabetes mellitus
    • Optic atrophy (progressive, bilateral)
    • Deafness (sensorineural)
  • It is also known as DIDMOAD.
  • Neurologic and psychiatric disturbances are prominent in most patients and can cause severe disability.

questions.solution:
Intra Neuronal inclusion bodies with their associated conditions are as follows:

Intraneuronal inclusion bodies Condition
Hirano Bodies Alzheimers disease
Bunina body ALS

questions.text: Confirmatory test for cushing’s syndrome is_______
questions.solution:
• Low dose DEX test is used for confirming cushing’s syndrome.
  • Other test for screening and confirmation of diagnosis is by:
    • 24hr urinary free cortisol excretion (3 times increased above normal )
    • Dexamethasone overnight test (plasma cortisol >50 nmol /L at 8-9 a.m after 1 mg of dexamethasone at 11p.m)
    • If Midnight plasma cortisol >130 nmol/ L [ or] midnight salivary cortisol >5 nmol/ L)
  • Low dose DEX test is positive if plasma cortisol level is >50nmol/L after 0.5 mg of dexamethasone q6h for 2 days.
  • Corticotrophin releasing hormone test is to differentiate between pituitary from ectopic source of ACTH in cushing. The test is positive if ACTH increases >40% at 15-30 minutes + cortisol increase >20% at 45-60 minutes after CRH 100 microgram I.V.
  • High dose DEX test A high dose of dexamethasone exerts negative feedback on pituitary ACTH-producing cells, but not on ectopic ACTH-producing cells or adrenal adenoma. The test is positive if cortisol suppressiom >50% after q6h 2 mg dexamethasone for 2 days.

questions.text: The clinical finding in the given image is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The above image depicts a classical fish mouth (microstomia) appearance seen in systemic sclerosis/scleroderma.

Scleroderma or Systemic Sclerosis (SSc) is an autoimmune rheumatic disease in which there is a 4:1 female predominance.

A wide spectrum of clinical features are seen in Scleroderma:

  • Severe pruritus
  • Initially, puffiness and non-pitting edema of fingers
  • The skin later becomes indurated, thickened, and fixed to underlying structures resulting in sclerodactyly
  • Vasospasm and digital ulceration
  • Most patients have dysphagia and GERD
  • Mask-like facies is seen due to the waxy nature of skin and lack of wrinkles, expressionless facies, mat‐like telangiectases, microstomia, perioral furrowing, and beak‐like nose.

The antibodies tested in systemic sclerosis include:

  • Antinuclear antibody (ANA) - positive in most cases of systemic sclerosis. The absence of this antibody suggests considering an alternate diagnosis.
  • Anticentromere antibody (ACA) - usually positive in limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis
  • Antitopoisomerase I (anti-Scl-70) antibody - usually positive with diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis 
  • Anti-RNA polymerase III antibody - usually positive with diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis.

Other options:

Option B: Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is an autoimmune disease that most commonly presents with arthralgia with early morning stiffness. Other important features of SLE include malar rash, discoid rash, photosensitivity, oral ulcers, pleuritis, pericarditis, and lupus nephritis. ANA, Anti-dsDNA antibodies, and anti-Smith antibodies are positive in SLE. 

Option C: Angular stomatitis is the soreness at the angles of the mouth extending outwards in the folds of the facial skin.

Option D: Hand-foot-and-mouth disease is caused by coxsackievirus. It is an exanthematous fever affecting mainly young children, characterized by oral and pharyngeal ulcerations and a vesicular rash of the palms and soles that may spread to the arms and legs.

Related Pearl: Diffuse Cutaneous Systemic Sclerosis Versus Limited Cutaneous Systemic Sclerosis

Characteristic feature Diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis Limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis
Skin involvement

Rapid progression

Involvement of the skin areas proximal to the knees or elbows or over the anterior chest, trunk, or abdomen

Slow progression

Limited to face and skin distal to the elbows and knees

 

 
Raynaud’s phenomenon

Less severe

 

Short history 

More severe; commonly associated with critical limb ischemia.

Long history 
Musculoskeletal Severe arthralgia, carpal tunnel syndrome, and tendon friction rubs Mild arthralgia
Pulmonary manifestation Interstitial lung disease more common Pulmonary artery hypertension (PAH) is equal in both
Scleroderma renal crisis Occurs usually <4 years of disease onset Very rare
Calcinosis cutis Less common More common & prominent
Auto-antibodies

Anti-topoisomerase I (Scl-70)

anti-RNA polymerase III

 Anti centromere

questions.text: True regarding the diagnostic criteria of obesity hypoventilation syndrome is _______
questions.solution:
• Diagnostic criteria of obesity hypoventilation syndrome includes:
    • BMI ≥30 kg/ m2
    • Paco2 ≥ 45 mmHg
    • Pao2 <70 mmHg
  • Also known as pickwickian syndrome.
  • Approximately 90% of the patients with obesity hypoventilation syndrome also have obstructive sleep apnoea that worsens during REM sleep.

questions.text: Kviem-siltzbach procedure is a specific diagnostic test for which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
• The Kviem-Siltzbach procedure is a specific diagnostic test for sarcoidosis.
  • An intradermal injection of specially prepared tissue derived from the spleen of a known sarcoidosis patient is biopsied 4–6 weeks after injection. If non caseating granulomas are seen, this is highly specific for the diagnosis of sarcoidosis.
  • There is no commercially available Kviem-Siltzbach reagent, and some locally prepared batches have lower specificity.
  • Thus, this test is of historic interest and is rarely used in current clinical practice.
  • Because the diagnosis of sarcoidosis can never be certain, over time other features may arise that lead to an alternative diagnosis.
  • Conversely, evidence for new organ involvement may eventually confirm the diagnosis of sarcoidosis.

questions.text: A 30 year old male patient presents with recurrent genital ulcer and uveitis. Oral examination shows the following findings.Which of the following statement is true about this condition?

choices.text: Chlamydia can be a preceding infection

questions.solution:
The image shows aphthous ulcer (which are painful and it heals without scar) and this is a case of Behcet's disease fulfilling the criteria which are recurrent oral ulceration + any 2 of the following conditions:

  • Recurrent genital ulcer
  • Eye lesion
  • Skin lesion
  • Pathergy test

 

Behcet's can be associated with SVC obstruction and it has an HLA B51 positivity.

Male and females have equal incidence.

questions.text: Most common cause of Empyema is ______
questions.solution:
• Frankly, purulent pleural fluid (empyema) is almost always caused by bacterial pneumonia.
  • Empyema thoracic is collection of pus in pleural space and is synonymous with grossly purulent exudative parapneumonic effusions.

questions.text: Most common metabolic abnormality seen in Addison’s disease is
questions.solution:
• Hyponatremia is a characteristic biochemical feature in primary adrenal insufficiency and is found in 80% of patients at presentation.
  • Hyperkalemia is present in 40% of patients at initial diagnosis.
  • Hyponatremia is primarily caused by mineralocorticoid deficiency but can also occur in secondary adrenal insufficiency due to diminished inhibition of antidiuretic hormone (ADH) release by cortisol, resulting in mild syndrome of inappropriate secretion of antidiuretic hormone(SIADH).
  • Most common symptom present in Addison’s disease is asthenia.

questions.text: Massive myoclonus is a hallmark of which stage of SSPE?
questions.solution:
Clinical stages of subacute sclerosis panencephalitis:

Stage  Clinical manifestations 
Stage I  Personality changes, failure in school, strange behaviour  
Stage II  Massive, repetitive, and frequent myoclonic jerks, seizures and dementia  
Stage III  Rigidity, extrapyramidal symptoms, and progressive unresponsiveness  
Stage IV  Coma, vegetative state, autonomic failure, and akinetic mutism

questions.text: Which of the following is false about Anaphylactoid purpura?

choices.text: Diagnosis is made using skin biopsy
It is a post infective phenomena

questions.solution:
• Anaphylactoid purpura was previously called as Henoch-schonlein purpura (HSP)
  • More common in children 4 to 7 yrs of age
  • Male : Female Ratio is 1.5:1
  • It is a post infective phenomena mostly preceded by URTI

Clinical Features:

  • Palpable purpura over buttock and lower limb (Hallmark)
  • Involves Mucus membranes
  • Arthralgia
  • IgA Nephropathy (Rare)

Treatment:

  • Reassurance (It has an excellent prognosis)

questions.text: Which of the following test gives the glycemic status over the prior 2 weeks duration?
questions.solution:
• Fructosamine is a glycated albumin that stays in the body for the period of 2 weeks.
  • Measurement of glycated hemoglobin (HbA1c) is the standard method for assessing long-term glycemic control.
  • When plasma glucose is consistently elevated, there is an increase in nonenzymatic glycation of hemoglobin; this alteration reflects the glycemic history over the previous 2–3 months, because erythrocytes have an average life span of 120 days (glycemic level in the preceding month contributes about 50% to the HbA1c value).

questions.text: Major susceptible gene for type 1 DM located on chromosome:
questions.solution:
• The major susceptibility gene for type 1 DM is located in the HLA region on chromosome 6.
  • Polymorphisms in the HLA complex account for 40–50% of the genetic risk of developing type 1 DM.
  • The concordance of type 1 DM in identical twins ranges between 40 and 60%, Most individuals with type 1 DM have the HLA DR3 and/or DR4 haplotype.
  • The haplotypes DQA1*0301, DQB1*0302, and DQB1*0201 are most strongly associated with type 1 DM. These haplotypes are present in 40% of children with type 1 DM as compared to 2% of the normal U.S. population. However, most individuals with predisposing haplotypes do not develop diabetes.
  • The haplotype DQA1*0102, DQB1*0602 is extremely rare in individuals with type 1 DM (<1%) and appears to provide protection from type 1 DM.
  • The risk of developing type 1 DM is increased tenfold in relatives of individuals with the disease, the risk is relatively low: 3–4% if the parent has type 1 DM and 5–15% in a sibling (depending on which HLA haplotypes are shared).
  • Most Individuals with type 1 DM do not have a first-degree relative with this disorder.

questions.text: Which of the following antibody in SLE is positive for hypercoagulable state?
questions.solution:
Anti phospholipid antibody is positive in SLE patients with hypercoagulable state.

Anti Histone  Drug induced lupus 
Anti Smith  Most specific antibody 
ANA  Most sensitive(best screening test) antibody 
Anti double stranded DNA  Good specificity (preferred in practice)

questions.text: In which of the following conditions  Means-lerman scratch  is present
questions.solution:
• A systolic pleuropericardial friction rub (Means-Lerman scratch) may be heard at the left second intercostal space during expiration resulting from rubbing of pericardium against the pleura and is thought to result from the hyperdynamic cardiac motion.
  • Means lerman scratch mimics the sound of pericardial rub.
  • Common cardiovascular manifestations of hyperthyroidism include palpitations, systolic hypertension, and fatigue.
  • Sinus tachycardia is present in ~40% of hyperthyroid patients, and atrial fibrillation is present in ~15%.
  • Elderly patients with hyperthyroidism may present with only cardiovascular manifestations of thyrotoxicosis such as sinus tachycardia, atrial fibrillation, and hypertension, all of which may be resistant to therapy until the hyperthyroidism is controlled.

questions.text: True statement regarding congenital hypothyroidism is :

choices.text: Upper end of tibial epiphyseal Centre present in x ray

questions.solution:
• The majority of infants appear normal at birth, and <10% are diagnosed based on clinical features, which include prolonged jaundice, feeding problems, hypotonia, enlarged tongue, delayed bone maturation and umbilical hernia.
  • Epiphyseal dysgenesis is pathognomonic.
  • Bone age is abnormal. 
  • Epiphyseal Centre that are normally present at birth are upper end of tibia, lower end of femur, talus, calcaneum, cuboid in ankle joint are absent in x-ray.
  • Permanent neurologic damage results if treatment is delayed.

questions.text: Second most common site for Deep brain stimulation in patients with parkinsonism is:
questions.solution:
• Second most common site useful for parkinsonism is Globus pallidus Internus.
  • First most common site useful is Subthalamic Nucleus.
  • Subthalamic nuclei and Globus pallidus both has been comparable to show equal results in the Deep brain stimulation test for parkinsonism.

Other targets for DBS are:

  • Ventral Intermediate Nucleus of Thalamus(VMI)
    • Relieves only tremors but other motor symptoms may not respond so this is less preferred for DBS.
  • Pedunculopontine Nucleus
    • Useful for Advanced Parkinsonism only.

questions.text: Myogenic reflex present in:
questions.solution:
Myogenic reflex present in afferent arteriole of kidney.

Auto regulation of renal blood flow is by 3 main mechanism

  • Autonomous vasoreactive (myogenic) reflex in the afferent arteriole
  • Tubuloglomerular feedback of afferent arteriole
  • Angiotensin II-mediated vasoconstriction of the efferent arteriole

The myogenic reflex is a first line of defense against fluctuations in renal blood flow.

Tubuloglomerular feedback (TGF) changes the rate of filtration and tubular flow by reflex vasoconstriction or dilatation of the afferent arteriole.

TGF is mediated by specialized cells in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle called the macula densa that act as sensors of solute concentration and tubular flow rate.

Autoregulation Of GFR by Angiotensin II:

questions.text: Gene for hereditary pancreatitis is located in
questions.solution:

questions.text: Short Bowel syndrome is characterized by all of the following except?
questions.solution:
Short bowel syndrome is characterized by hypergastrinemia due to reduced small intestinal catabolism of gastrin.

Causes of Short bowel Syndrome:

  • Mesentric vascular disease- Mesenteric ischemia
  • Primary musosal and sub mucosal disease- Crohns disease
  • Operations without preexisting small intestinal disease- Jejuno ileal bypass for obesity.

questions.text: A patient presented with chronic crampy abdominal pain, rectal bleeding, and tenesmus. Endoscopic examination revealed multiple, continuous lesions in the rectum and rectosigmoid without normal mucosa in between. The mucosa was red and the surface was fine granular like sandpaper. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is ulcerative colitis (UC).

UC is a mucosal disease that primarily involves rectum and extends proximally to involves some parts or whole of the colon. It can cause proctitis, proctocolitis, and colitis.

The involvement of the mucosa in UC is continuous without any normal mucosa in between. The various mucosal changes in different stages of UC are as follows: 

  • Mild disease - mucosa appears erythematous with fine granular surface resembling sandpaper
  • Severe disease - mucosa is hemorrhagic, edematous, and ulcerated
  • Long-standing disease - inflammatory polyps (pseudopolyps) due to epithelial regeneration.

Microscopically UC shows the following findings: 

  • Inflammation that is limited to mucosa and submucosa
  • Distortion of the crypt architecture with the following changes - 
    • Bifid and reduced number of crypts
    • Gap between the crypt base and muscularis mucosae is seen
    • Cryptitis and crypt abscesses - due to crypt invasion by neutrophils
  • Basal plasma cells and multiple basal lymphoid aggregates
  • Mucosal vascular congestion with edema and focal haemorrhage 
  • Mucosal inflammatory cell infiltration by neutrophils, lymphocytes, plasma cells, and macrophages 
  • Backwash ileitis with:
    • Villous atrophy and crypt regeneration
    • Increased neutrophil and mononuclear inflammation in the lamina propria
    • Patchy cryptitis and crypt abscesses

The below image shows pseudopolyps in ulcerative colitis.

The below image shows the histology of ulcerative colitis.

Clinical features of UC include: Crampy abdominal pain, rectal bleeding, passing of mucus in stools and tenesmus. 

Other options: 

Option A: Crohn's disease (CD) manifests as ileocolitis with right lower quadrant pain, palpable mass, fever, leukocytosis and weight loss. Other features like elevated ESR and CRP are seen. Endoscopy shows rectal sparing, fistulas, skip lesions and transmural inflammation. 

Option B: Diverticulitis is a close differential for Crohn's disease and is characterised by features such as fever, abdominal pain, mass, elevated ESR and leukocytosis. Endoscopic features are less appreciable in this condition than in CD.

Option C: Ischaemic colitis is typically characterised by sudden onset of left lower quadrant pain and bleeding per rectum following repair of abdominal aortic aneurysm or in a patient with cardiac/peripheral vascular disease. 

Related Pearl: Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD)

 

  Crohn's disease Ulcerative colitis
Age of onset  2nd-4th decades & 7th-9th decades 2nd-4th decades & 7th-9th decades 
Most common presentation Ileocolitis with rectal sparing Proctitis (rectum)
Protective factors  None

questions.text: All of the following statements are true regarding Riedel’s thyroiditis except

choices.text: Thyroid gland is stony hard in consistency
Tamoxifen and steroids are useful in treatment

questions.solution:
• Riedel’s thyroiditis presents with hypothyroidism.
  • Riedel’s thyroiditis is a rare disorder that typically occurs in middle-aged women.
  • It presents with an insidious, painless goiter with local symptoms due to compression of the esophagus, trachea, neck veins, or recurrent laryngeal nerves.
  • Dense fibrosis disrupts normal gland architecture and can extend outside the thyroid capsule.
  • The goiter is hard, nontender often asymmetric, and fixed, leading to suspicion of a malignancy.
  • Diagnosis requires open biopsy as FNA biopsy is usually inadequate.
  • Treatment is directed to surgical relief of compressive symptoms.
  • Tamoxifen and steroids may also be beneficial.

questions.text: Natalizumab is useful in _______
questions.solution:
• Natalizumab is a monoclonal antibody proven to be useful for crohns disease. 
  • It is a recombinant humanized IgG4 antibody against Alpha 4 integrins which is effective in induction and maintenance of remission in crohns disease patients.
  • It has been approved for the treatment of patients who are refractory /intolerant to anti TNF therapy.
  • Medical management of Moderate to severe Crohns disease is as follows ( 5 ASA being the mainstay of treatment )

questions.text: Identify the given picture:
questions.solution:
Middleton's Maneuver. 

  • Examiner stands on left side of the patient facing the foot end of the bed.
  • The hooked fingers of the right hand are placed under the costal margin and with left hand pressure is exerted over postero lateral aspect of lower thorax.
  • Spleen is left at deep inspiratory phase.(Palpatory test)

Percussion for splenic dullness is accomplished with any of the three techniques:

Nixon’s method: The patient is placed on the right side so that the spleen lies above the colon and stomach. Percussion begins at the lower level of pulmonary resonance in the posterior axillary line and proceeds diagonally along a perpendicular line toward the lower mid anterior costal margin. The upper border of dullness is normally 6–8 cm above the costal margin. Dullness >8 cm in an adult is presumed to indicate splenic enlargement.

Castell’s method: With the patient supine, percussion in the lowest intercostal space in the anterior axillary line (eighth or ninth) produces a resonant note if the spleen is normal in size. This is true during expiration or full inspiration. A dull percussion note on full inspiration suggests splenomegaly.

Percussion of Traube’s semilunar space: The borders of Traube’s space are the sixth rib superiorly, the left midaxillary line laterally,and the left costal margin inferiorly. The patient is supine with the left arm slightly abducted. During normal breathing, this space is percussed from medial to lateral margins, yielding a normal resonant sound. A dull percussion note suggests splenomegaly.

questions.text: Which of the following is seen with phenytoin therapy?
questions.solution:
Phenytoin causes the following side effects:

questions.text: Most common diabetic cranial mononeuropathy is
questions.solution:
The most common mononeuropathies are

  • Median neuropathy at the wrist.
  • Ulnar neuropathy at the elbow.
  • Peroneal neuropathy at the fibular head.
  • In regard to cranial mononeuropathies, seventh nerve palsies are relatively common but may have other, nondiabetic etiologies.
  • In diabetics, a third nerve palsy is most common, followed by sixth nerve, and, less frequently, fourth nerve palsies.

questions.text: Upper Dorsal pontine syndrome is otherwise called _______
questions.solution:
Caused by obstruction of long circumferential branches of basilar artery.

Features:

Clinical Feature  Due to damage to 
Ipsilateral paralysis of muscles of mastication and sensory loss in face    Sensory and motor nuclei and tracts of CN V 
Ipsilateral ataxia + coarse intention tremor   Superior and middle cerebellar peduncle 
Horizontal Gaze palsy may occur   - 
Contralateral loss of sensory areas of body   Spinothalamic tract and medical lemniscus 
Contralateral hemiparesis of face and body may occur with ventral extension of lesion   Corticospinal tract

questions.text: Disease activity score is used in which of the following disease ?
questions.solution:
DAS score counted over 28 joints is used to decide the treatment.

  • For mild cases – DMARD monotherapy
  • For moderate cases – DMARD combination therapy
  • For Severe cases – Combination of DMARD therapy but consider early use of biologicals

questions.text: About syringomyelia all are true except:

choices.text: There is no satisfactory treatment available
It is associated with Chiari type 2 malformations

questions.solution:
• All cases are associated with Chiari type 1 malformations in which the cerebellar tonsils protrude through the foramen magnum and into the cervical spinal canal.
  • Syringomyelia is a developmental cavity of the cervical cord that may enlarge and produce progressive myelopathy.
  • The sensory deficit has a distribution that is “suspended” over the nape of the neck, shoulders, and upper arms (cape distribution) or in the hands.
  • Muscle wasting in the lower neck, shoulders, arms, and hands with asymmetric or absent reflexes in the arms reflects expansion of the cavity in the gray matter of the cord.
  • Treatment of syringomyelia is generally unsatisfactory.

questions.text: Not an internal manifestation of tuberous sclerosis is?
questions.solution:
• Adenoma sebacium is an external manifestation of tuberous sclerosis not an internal manifestation.
  • In tuberous sclerosis, the earliest cutaneous sign is macular hypomelanosis, referred to as an ash leaf spot.
  • These lesions are often present at birth and are usually multiple; however, detection may require Wood’s lamp examination, especially in fair-skinned individuals.
  • The pigment within them is reduced, but not absent.
  • The average size is 1–3 cm, and the common shapes are polygonal and lance-ovate.
  • Examination of the patient for additional cutaneous signs such as multiple angiofibromas of the face (adenoma sebaceum), ungual and gingival fibromas, fibrous plaques of the forehead, and connective tissue nevi (shagreen patches) is recommended.
  • It is important to remember that an ash leaf spot on the scalp will result in a circumscribed patch of lightly pigmented hair. Internal manifestations include seizures, mental retardation, central nervous system (CNS) and retinal hamartomas, pulmonary lymphangioleiomyomatosis (women), renal angiomyolipomas, and cardiac rhabdomyomas.

questions.text: Metabolic encephalopathy presents with
questions.solution:
Anomic aphasia is the single most common language disturbance seen in head trauma, metabolic encephalopathy, and Alzheimer’s disease.

Articulation, comprehension, and repetition are intact, but confrontation naming, word finding, and spelling are impaired. Word-finding pauses are uncommon, so language output is fluent but paraphasic, circumlocutious, and uninformative.

The lesion sites can be anywhere within the left hemisphere language network, including the middle and inferior temporal gyri.

questions.text: RYR1 gene mutations are associated with
questions.solution:
Malignant hyperthermia is associated with RYR1 gene mutations.

This gene encodes skeletal muscle ryanodine receptor ,the calcium channel that releases calcium from sarcoplasmic reticulum.

Mutations in the ryanodine receptor are associated with:

  • Central core myopathy
  • Malignant hyperthermia

questions.text: The features given in the images is characteristic of
questions.solution:
• The image shows classical Keratoderma blenorrhagica which is an extra articular manifestation of reactive arthritis.
  • Previously this condition was called Reiter’s disease.

Other extra articular manifestations includes:

  • Uveitis
  • Diarrhoea

Articular manifestations include:

  • Asymmetrical oligo arthritis of large joint
  • Additive type of arthritis

Diagnosis:

  • Mostly Clinical , shows HLA B27 positivity

Treatment: 

  • First line- NSAIDS (>80% resolution) 
  • Start with sulphasalazine & Methotrexate if no resolution or if erosions are present

questions.text: Post ictal confusion is absent in
questions.solution:
Post ictal confusion is characteristically absent in absence seizures:

  • Typical absence seizures are characterized by sudden, brief lapses of consciousness without loss of postural control.
  • The seizure typically lasts for only seconds, consciousness returns as suddenly as it was lost, and there is no postictal confusion.
  • In all others options post ictal confusion is present.

questions.text: True about the ECG is?

choices.text: AICDs are  used for occasional trigeminy

questions.solution:
Every Third beat is ectopic.

  • The image shows a pattern of 2 normal sinus rhythm beats followed by premature ventricular beats.
  • This is seen in ventricular trigeminy.
  • Trigemini is an irregular heart beat or arrthymia comprising of a repetitive series of 2 normal heart beat and one premature heart beat.
  • With regard to ECG activity readings, Trigeminy refers to a rhythm where in every third beat is ectopic.
  • That is starting from some other area and not from sinus node.
  • PVCs refer to early depolarization commencing in the ventricle instead of the sinus node.
  • Ventricular Trigeminy is defined as occurrence of PVCs every third beat.
  • Medical treatment of trigemini PVC is Anti arrhythmic medications and beta blockers.
  • Surgical treatment includes PACE MAKERS
  • Automated implantable Cardioverter Defibrillator (AICDS) are great for treating serious PVCs but are not used for patients with mild or occasional trigemini.

questions.text: The following drugs are contra-indicated for the treatment of atrial fibrillation associated with the WPW syndrome:
questions.solution:
In WPW digoxin or calcium channel blockers may increase anterograde conduction through the bypass tract, so they should be avoided. (increases ventricular rate >300 by decreasing the refractoriness of accessory pathways)

Treatment for such induced arrhythmias:

  • IV Procainamide
  • DC cardioversion

questions.text: In patients with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy maximum mutations are found in which gene
questions.solution:
• Mutations in gene for b- Mysoin heavy chain are associated with 40% of the families with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.
  • Troponin T mutations- 15% of the families. 
  • α- tropomyosin mutations ~5% of the families

questions.text: D-Dimer value may be increased in all of the following except:
questions.solution: D-Dimer values are falsely decreased in patients receiving anti coagulation therapy.

questions.text:
A 36-year-old female patient has hyperparathyroidism, pituitary adenoma, and gastrinoma with cutaneous angiofibromas. What is the likely diagnosis?

MEN - Multiple endocrine neoplasia
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests a diagnosis of MEN 1 syndrome.

Multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) syndromes are characterized by tumors of two or more endocrine glands. There are four major types of MEN (MEN 1–4), and they either show an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance or occur sporadically. 

MEN 1, also known as Wermer’s syndrome, is characterized by the triad of parathyroid, pancreatic islet cell, and anterior pituitary tumors. Adrenal cortical tumors, carcinoid tumors, facial angiofibromas, collagenomas, thyroid tumors, and lipomas may also occur. MEN 1-associated tumors are usually multiple, larger, and more aggressive, resulting in resistance to treatment and poor patient outcomes.

  1. Parathyroid tumors- primary hyperparathyroidism is the most common feature of MEN 1. Hypercalcemia with or without symptoms (polyuria, polydipsia, constipation, dyspepsia), nephrolithiasis, and osteitis fibrosa cystica may also occur. All four parathyroid glands are usually affected with multiple adenomas or hyperplasia. 
  2. Pancreatic islet cell tumors- these are neuroendocrine tumors, including:
    • Gastrinoma (gastrin-secreting tumors)- associated with increased gastric acid secretion and multiple peptic ulcers (Zollinger-Ellison syndrome). Patients may present with diarrhea and steatorrhea. Gastrinomas are the major cause of mortality and morbidity. 
    • Insulinoma (insulin-secreting tumors)- patients present with hypoglycemic symptoms (weakness, headaches, sweating, seizures, weight gain) that develop after fasting or exertion and improve after glucose intake. Along with increased plasma insulin levels and hypoglycemia, increased C peptide and proinsulin levels help in diagnosing the condition.
    • Glucagonoma (glucagon-secreting tumors)- may be associated with necrolytic migratory erythema, weight loss, anemia, and stomatitis. 
    • VIPomas (Vasoactive intestinal peptide [VIP]-secreting tumors): The VIPoma syndrome, also known as Verner-Morrison syndrome, is characterized by watery diarrhea, hypokalemia, and achlorhydria. These are mostly located in the tail of the pancreas.
    • PPomas (Pancreatic polypeptide-secreting tumors) and nonfunctioning pancreatic tumors- are associated with a worse prognosis as they often go undiagnosed due to the absence of both clinical features and biochemical abnormalities.
  3. Pituitary tumors- manifestations depend on the hormone secreted (symptoms of hyperprolactinemia, acromegaly, or Cushing’s disease) and tumor size (visual disturbances or hypopituitarism due to compression of the optic chiasm or normal pituitary tissue). 

Surgical excision of the nonmetastatic tumor after localization is the curative treatment. Appropriate medical therapy can be used for some tumors when surgery is contraindicated or unsuccessful (calcimemetics for parathyroid tumors, parietal cell H+-K+-ATPase inhibitors for gastrinomas). In case of metastasis, chemotherapy, hormonal therapy, radiation therapy, and artery embolization may be successful.

MEN 1 occurs due to a mutation in the MEN1 gene located on chromosome 11q13. Mutational genetic analysis is necessary to confirm the clinical diagnosis and identify family members who harbor the mutation and require screening for tumor detection and early treatment.

Other options:

Options B and C: MEN 2, also called Sipple’s syndrome, is characterized by medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC), pheochromocytomas, and parathyroid tumors. This occurs due to mutations of the rearranged during transfection (RET) protooncogene. There are three clinical variants -

  1. MEN 2A (most common): MTC is associated with pheochromocytomas in 50% of patients and parathyroid tumors in 20% of patients. MEN 2A may also be associated with Hirschsprung’s disease and cutaneous lichen amyloidosis.
  2. MEN 2B (MEN 3): MTC is associated with pheochromocytoma, along with Marfanoid habitus; mucosal neuromas of the lips, tongue, and eyelids; medullated corneal fibers; and intestinal autonomic ganglion dysfunction leading to multiple diverticulae and megacolon. Parathyroid tumors are usually absent.
  3. MTC only (FMTC): MTC is the only manifestation.

Option D: MEN 4 is characterized by a combination of MEN 1–associated tumors and CDKN1B mutation-related tumors (gonadal, adrenal, renal, and thyroid tumors).

Related Pearl: MEN 1 Syndrome Features

Chromosome 11q13 / MEN1 gene

Also known as Wermer’s syndrome

Characteristic tumors seen in:

  • Parathyroid adenoma – 90 % - Most common overall
  • Entero pancreatic tumors - Most common functioning tumor is gastrinoma (most common site is duodenum)
  • Pituitary adenoma – Most common is prolactinoma
  • Mnemonic – Par Pan Pit – in decreasing order of frequency

Associated tumors are:

  • Angiofibroma
  • Collagenomas
  • Adrenal cortical tumors
  • Lipoma
  • Neuroendocrine tumors - gastric, thymic, lungs
  • Meningioma
  • Pheochromocytoma
  • Carcinoid tumors, usually of the foregut

Related Pearl: MEN 2 Syndrome Features

MEN 2A

  • Known as Sipple’s syndrome
  • Chromosome 10 / RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Parathyroid adenoma (10–25%)

MEN 2B

  • Known commonly as MEN 3
  • Chromosome 10/ RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (>90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Other associated abnormalities include: (40–50%)
      • Mucosal neuromas
      • Marfanoid habitus
      • Medullated corneal nerve fibers
      • Megacolon

questions.text: All of the following are features of McCune Albright syndrome except?
questions.solution:
McCune Albright syndrome consist of:

  • Poly ostotic fibrous dysplasia
  • Pigmented skin patches
  • Endocrine disorders like acromegaly, adrenal adenoma and autonomous ovarian function.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old male patient came with back pain and stiffness. He was found to have sacroiliitis on imaging and was diagnosed with ankylosing spondylitis. He is positive for an HLA marker. This marker positivity is also seen in _____.
  1. Psoriatic spondylitis
  2. Reactive arthritis due to Shigella
  3. Rheumatoid arthritis
  4. Behcet’s disease
questions.solution:
In the above clinical scenario of ankylosing spondylitis (AS), there will be positivity for HLA-B27. This marker positivity is also seen in psoriatic spondylitis (1) and reactive arthritis (2) due to Shigella.

HLA-B27 is also found to be positive in the following conditions:

  • Psoriatic spondylitis: Some patients with psoriatic arthritis have axial joint involvement without peripheral involvement, which presents similarly to AS.
  • Reactive arthritis: Acute non-purulent arthritis occurs a few days after a systemic infection or an infection elsewhere in the body. It is usually seen following enteric or urogenital infection. Organisms causing these infections are Shigella, Salmonella, Yersinia, and Chlamydia.

Ankylosing spondylitis is a chronic inflammatory disease affecting the spine and sacroiliac joint. It is more common in young males and strongly associates with HLA-B27.

Clinically, patients present with recurring backache, which worsens in the early morning or with inactivity and improves with exercise. Later, they develop fatigue, pain, joint swellings, and heel pain.

Extra-articular manifestations include uveitis, aortic incompetence, carditis, and apical lobe fibrosis.

X-ray findings:

  • Erosion of sacroiliac joints - sacroiliitis
  • Squaring of vertebrae and bamboo spine appearance

Other options:

  • Behcet's disease - HLA-B51 positive
  • Rheumatoid arthritis - HLA DR4 positive

Related Pearl: HLA association with diseases

questions.text: Type of MODY associated with renal cyst is
questions.solution:
• MODY 5 is associated with renal cyst.
  • Most common type of MODY- MODY 3.

questions.text: Selective proteinuria occurs due to defect in
questions.solution:
• The foot processes of epithelial cells (podocytes) cover the urinary side of the glomerular basement membrane and produce a series of narrow channels (slit diaphragms) to allow molecular passage of small solutes and water but not proteins.
  • Some glomerular disease such as minimal change disease, cause fusion of glomerular epithelial cell foot processes, resulting in predominantly selective loss of albumin.
  • Other glomerular diseases can present with disruption of the basement membrane and slit diaphragms (e.g., by immune complex deposition), resulting in losses of albumin and other plasma proteins.
  • The fusion of foot processes causes increased pressure across the capillary basement membrane, resulting in areas with larger pore sizes (and more severe “nonselective” proteinuria).
  • The normal glomerular endothelial cell forms a barrier composed of pores of ~100 nm that retain blood cells but offer little impediment to passage of most proteins.
  • The glomerular basement membrane traps most large proteins (>100 kDa).
